Award.AwardTitle: Calcium in Bridgmanite in the Deep Mantle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Volcanic activity, such as that seen in Hawaii today and Yellowstone in the recent past, are linked to heat coming from deep in the Earth's interior. Although seismic studies have identified a few large scale candidate structures in the deep mantle that could represent the source of heat or material to feeds these large volcanic centers, little is known about the origin and nature of those structures. In this project, the team will investigate probable compositional changes in the dominant mineral in the Earth's deep mantle, in order to better understand the nature of the global-scale structures in the deep mantle that could affect our planet's changing surface. It is expected that the experiments to be conducted in this project will result in advancing our knowledge of the formation of deeply rooted volcanism and their evolution. Such knowledge is important in a range of topics that include assessing some types of natural hazard and providing insights into the processes that led to the formation of the Earth as a planet. The project will support undergraduate research at Arizona State University, providing laboratory research opportunities for students interested in the geosciences.

Preliminary experiments suggest that Ca, Calcium, dissolves into bridgmanite (the dominant lower mantle mineral) at the pressure-temperature conditions of the deep mantle. In this project, it is planned to measure the pressure-temperature conditions where Ca enters into the crystal structure of bridgmanite. An additional goal of the study will be to measure the physical properties of Ca-bearing bridgmanite to compare with the properties of the seismically identified large scale mantle structures, such as Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces. The proposed experiments include in situ X-ray measurements at high pressure-temperature and chemical analysis of the recovered samples using electron microscopy. Because Ca-bearing minerals play an important role in the storage capacity of the lower mantle for heat producing elements, this research project is expected to close a gap in our knowledge of how heat producing elements are distributed among different geochemical structures in the deep mantle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lower mantle represents more than 50% of the Earth’s volume and has played important roles for the dynamic and chemical evolution of our planet. In order to understand the composition, structure, and dynamic evolution of the lower mantle, it is essential to have accurate knowledge on the mineralogy of the region. It has been believed that calcium is incorporated in a perovskite-structured CaSiO3 mineral in the lower mantle. However, there is another perovskite-structured mineral in the lower mantle, which is bridgmanite, the dominant mineral phase of the region. Structural similarity between minerals often leads to mutual solubility. However, studies so far have been unclear if calcium can dissolve in bridgmanite or not in the deep mantle conditions.  

The major goal of this project is to study bridgmanite focusing on the solubility of calcium in the crystal structure. From the experimental results, we also have studied how the mineralogy can affect the dynamics and structure of the Earth’s lower mantle.  

Through new experiments at synchrotron X-ray facilities, we have obtained conclusive evidence that calcium dissolves in bridgmanite at the conditions expected for the lower half of the mantle. The experimental results indicate that lower mantle can be divided into two layers (two-perovskite layer at shallower depths and single-perovskite layer at the greater depths). The data also show that the boundary would develop a large topography (more than 500 km in depth) in response to lateral temperature variations in the lower mantle. The depth of the mineralogy transition coincides with the depth range where many seismic and geophysical changes have been documented in recent years, potentially providing an explanation for those enigmatic observations. The lower single-perovskite layer should have experienced thinning with cooling of the Earth over the geological history. This time-dependent change of the deep mantle may provide new opportunities to understand geological evolution of the surface and the deep mantle processes. Furthermore, our experiment provides new information on how heat producing elements, such as Uranium and Thorium, are stored in the deep mantle, providing key knowledge for advancing integrated knowledge of the Earth’s evolution. 

The scientific activities in this project have also supported the PI Shim’s effort to link research and education. Shim has developed teaching modules and codes for data analysis courses in Earth and Planetary Sciences. The modules have been developed and used for teaching undergraduate and graduate students at Arizona State University. Such an activity has gained visibility from scientific community. PI Shim has organized a session on linking scientific research and education in American Geophysical Union meeting in 2019. He gave an invited presentation on the topic in American Geophysical Union meeting in 2020.
